title: Output Shaft - Disassembly

body.body: The numbers in brackets in the following text refer to the exploded view on
Working from the opposite end to the drive sprocket, dismantle the output shaft as follows.
Remove the output shaft bearing (1) and plain thrust washer (2).
Mark one side of first gear to show its correct orientation.
Remove first gear (3) from the shaft, complete with the plain bush (4) which runs inside the gear.
Mark one side of fifth gear to show its correct orientation.
Remove fifth gear (6) from the shaft.
Remove the circlip (7) and splined thrust washer (8) from in front of fourth gear.
Mark one side of fourth gear to show its correct orientation.
Remove fourth gear (9) complete with the splined bush which runs inside the gear (10).
Note their orientation and remove the splined lock washers (11 and 12).
Mark one side of third gear to show its correct orientation.
Remove third gear (14) off the shaft complete with the splined bush (13) which runs inside the gear.
Remove the circlip (16) from in front of sixth gear.
Mark one side of sixth gear to show its correct orientation.
Remove sixth gear (17) from the shaft.
Remove the circlip (18) from in front of second gear.
Mark one side of second gear to show its correct orientation.
Remove second gear (21) from the shaft, complete with the plain bush (20) which runs inside the gear.
Position the output shaft (22) in a vice that has soft jaws fitted.
Tighten the vice to prevent the shaft from turning and release the tab washer (28) from the output sprocket nut (29), then release the nut.
Remove the output sprocket nut (29), tab washer (28) and sprocket (27).
If it is found necessary to replace the large bearing (24) at the end of the shaft, use a press to remove both the bearing and output shaft sprocket spacer (25) together.
Always wear eye, face, hand protection and overalls when you use a press.
Components can break up when pressed and cause sharp pieces to be thrown at high speed.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in minor to moderate injury.

Working from the opposite end to the drive sprocket, dismantle the output shaft as follows.

Remove the plain thrust washer (5).
Mark one side of fifth gear to show its correct orientation.
Remove fifth gear (6) from the shaft.
Remove the circlip (7) and splined thrust washer (8) from in front of fourth gear.
Mark one side of fourth gear to show its correct orientation.
Remove fourth gear (9) complete with the splined bush which runs inside the gear (10).
Note their orientation and remove the splined lock washers (11 and 12).
Mark one side of third gear to show its correct orientation.
Remove third gear (14) off the shaft complete with the splined bush (13) which runs inside the gear.
Remove the splined thrust washer (15).
Remove the circlip (16) from in front of sixth gear.
Mark one side of sixth gear to show its correct orientation.
Remove sixth gear (17) from the shaft.
Remove the circlip (18) from in front of second gear.
Remove the splined thrust washer (19).
Mark one side of second gear to show its correct orientation.
Remove second gear (21) from the shaft, complete with the plain bush (20) which runs inside the gear.
Position the output shaft (22) in a vice that has soft jaws fitted.
Tighten the vice to prevent the shaft from turning and release the tab washer (28) from the output sprocket nut (29), then release the nut.
Remove the output sprocket nut (29), tab washer (28) and sprocket (27).
Collect the output shaft seal (26).
If it is found necessary to replace the large bearing (24) at the end of the shaft, use a press to remove both the bearing and output shaft sprocket spacer (25) together.
Always wear eye, face, hand protection and overalls when you use a press.
Components can break up when pressed and cause sharp pieces to be thrown at high speed.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in minor to moderate injury.
